title: BC-Business News Digest
text: Here are AP Business News' latest coverage plans, top stories and promotable content. All times EDT. New & Developing: — Adds: NETFLIX-PRICE INCREASE, BIKRAM YOGA-COPYRIGHT, DEM 2016-CLINTON-WALL STREET, FACEBOOK-REACTIONS, BEER MERGER TOP STORIES: CONGRESS-VOLKSWAGEN — Volkswagen's top U.S. executive offers deep apologies yet seeks to distance himself from the emissions scandal enveloping the world's largest automaker, asserting top corporate officials had no knowledge of the cheating software installed in 11 million diesel cars. By Michael Biesecker and Matthew Daly. SENT: 900 words, photos, audio, video. With: VOLKSWAGEN-CONSUMERS — Paying owners for the lost value of their cars is among the options under consideration as Volkswagen seeks solutions to its emissions-rigging scandal. By Tom Krisher. SENT: 400 words. And: VOLKSWAGEN — German prosecutors carry out searches in connection with their investigation of the Volkswagen emissions scandal, seeking material that would help clarify who was responsible for the cheating. By Geir Moulson. SENT: 670 words, photos. AIRLINES WE LOVE TO HATE — Many travelers are lured to Spirit and Frontier by low fares only to recount tales of lousy services and countless fees. Now government data backs up those claims. By David Koenig. SENT: 1,060 words, photos, graphic. With: AIRLINES-DELAYS — More flights are arriving on time but consumer complaints about the airlines have risen sharply. SENT: 300 words, glance. UAW-FIAT CHRYSLER — Fiat Chrysler avoids an expensive strike at its U.S. plants after reaching a tentative labor agreement with the United Auto Workers union. By Dee-Ann Durbin. SENT: 420 words, photos. APPLE-HARRY POTTER ENHANCED — The "Harry Potter" books are coming to life with more than 200 new illustrations, many animated or interactive, in enhanced e-books made for Apple devices. Series creator J.K. Rowling also goes deeper with a handful of pop-up annotations. By Anick Jesdanun. SENT: 600 words, photo. NETFLIX-PRICE INCREASE — Netflix is raising the price of its Internet video service by $1 for new customers in the U.S., Canada and some Latin America countries to help cover its escalating costs for shows such as "House of Cards" and other original programming. By Michael Liedtke. SENT: 600 words, photo. 1 of 5
